data.text:
More Information

Find current facts and statistics about Duke.

Ask a librarian about publications intended to help high school students choose colleges, like the U.S. News & World Report. These magazines usually include a description of the institution, figures for tuition, enrollment, makeup of the student body, the number of faculty, financial aid data and admissions statistics.

Notes:

Find current facts and statistics about Duke.

Figures from 1990 onward are given for the fall semester of the year indicated and were taken from the university's annual reports and financial statements. Earlier figures are taken from bulletins and other sources as available. Due to differences in accounting methods, figures prior to 1990 are not always comparable with the figures for later years.

The tuition figure is for first-year students in Trinity College of Arts & Sciences and does not include room, board and fees. Tuition in the graduate and professional schools varies.

The figures for faculty and students are full-time equivalent (FTE) figures for the fall semester.

For financial data since 2002, see past financial reports at Year in Review and the current financial report.

The value given for the endowment is the market value at the time the annual report is released. The figure does not include the value of funds held by other parties (e.g., The Duke Endowment).
